newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS / Bay Networks calls.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS / Bay Networks calls.

text.p: Bay Networks Inc calls attracted broad-based speculative bids amid growing optimism over the firm's share price, traders said.
September calls with strike prices of 25.0, 27.5 and 30.0 were the most active contracts on the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), with the 27.5 call trading 6,764 contracts.

"I think it's mostly speculation," said Peter Najarian of Mercury Trading, designated primary market maker for Bay Networks options at CBOE. "The stock has been beaten up to a level where...I think people finally decided it was overdone."
The stock was up 1-7/8 on the day to 27-1/8. It had tumbled to a low of 20-1/4 on July 24 from a high of 43-3/8 on February 29.
Traders agreed that Bay Network was one of the few stocks that stood out with sizeable gains amid a generally subdued market today.

"What we have seen a little bit of lately is a pick-up in some of the speculative activity," said Rod Jamieson, vice president of option strategy at EVEREN Securities. "And this one looks like another speculation."
He noted that all strikes near the at-the-money level in September, October and December had large total volume, without any inflation by huge institutional orders.
Implied volatilities for September calls have spiked up towards 60 percent from the mid-40s area.
There was vague talk of a big brokerage firm upgrading the stock, but traders were unsure what the optimism was based on.
One trader said it was probably one of bottom-picking plays seen from time to time in battered technology shares like Micron Technology Inc, Iomega Corp.
Thursday's sharp run-up in Zenith Electronics Corp might have inspired such interest, he said.
Najarian added that there was good interest in selling puts, reflecting the growing bullishness.
He dismissed possibilities of takeover-related buying.

"There's always speculation on companies like Bay Net," he said. "From a standpoint of takeover, however, as big a company as they are, it's going to take quite a large company to try to take over. So I think those rumors are false."
